content.body: I'm curious, does the re-entrancy problem discussed, or the potential of it, also exist in dynamic import? because by the time you can trigger a lazy module that operates on an already imported module, is if you are at the ancestor module that imports both. that means that C has already evaluated, and it's state is set. B is similar to an async dynamic import, but without the async tick. Why does the re-entrancy hazard come up only in the case where there is no async tick?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I'm curious, does the re-entrancy problem discussed, or the potential of it, also exist in dynamic import? because by the time you can trigger a lazy module that operates on an already imported module, is if you are at the ancestor module that imports both. that means that C has already evaluated, and it's state is set. B is similar to an async dynamic import, but without the async tick. Why does the re-entrancy hazard come up only in the case where there is no async tick?

content.body: I think I don't quite understand what the hazard is, curious to hear more
